comment._content: Scandal from Detroit: Arthur Little, a druggist, sought to divorce his wife Alma in 1914-15, because she "concealed Negro blood in her veins." Mrs. Little was a pale blonde, and denied that she had any African ancestry. She came to New York to visit the anthropologist Franz Boas, who pronounced that "If this golden-haired blond really has Negro blood in her veins, not a husband in the world can feel assured that his wife is not a Negress." The couple divorced on grounds of cruelty instead. This story turns up in Elizabeth M. Smith-Pryor, Property Rites: The Rhinelander Trial, Passing, and the Protection of Whiteness (UNC Press 2009): 166.

comment._content:
From the Batavia NY Daily News, 19 December 1914, p. 4:
HER RACE UNKNOWN. Woman Declared a Negress Will Ask Aid of Scientists Ann Arbor, Mich., Dec. 19.--In an effort to obtain scientific evidence in support of her contention that she has no negro blood in her veins, as charged by her husband, who seeks a divorce. Mrs. Alma Little of Detroid consulted several medical experts connected with the University of Michigan. Every test showed the woman to be white, yet such authorities as Dr. Victor Vaughn, president of the American Medical Association, admitted he dare not make an affidavit to such a statement, saying that no method has been discovered by which it is possible to definitely to determine by scientific methods if a person had negro blood. Mrs. Little is arranging a journey to Eastern cities and to seek the aid of such scientists as George Grant, Franz Boas, and Alex Herdlcka in determining her race.
